Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding Gender Differences in STEM Academic Careers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds research that uses data from the National Center for Science and Engineering Statistics (NCSES) to consider women's academic career progression in STEM disciplines. The team will use a new dataset, the Survey of Doctorate Recipients Productivity Database (SDRPD), which includes publication and patent data for PhD scientists who participate in the NCSES Survey of Doctorate Recipients. The team will first produce a technical report that details the characteristics of these data to aid a broad and interdisciplinary community of scientists. They then plan to use the data to evaluate possible causes for the already documented gender gaps in STEM publication and citation by controlling for demographic, family, and employer characteristics. The results of this project can be used by universities and funders who want to develop policies designed to address barriers faced by women in academic STEM disciplines.

Economic theory predicts that gender differences in productivity will lead to gender differences in career outcomes. Without data that includes information both on productivity and on individual demographic factors, we cannot tell, for example, if women in STEM face a larger productivity gap if they have children, or if women scientists find it more difficult to move for a new job. The project will also evaluate the quality of SDRPD and will provide technical documentation for the research community interested in using the data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The dearth of women in the most intensive math-intensive fields is a fait accompli by the time that scientists receive their PhDs. Our research has synthesized the literature and conducted additional analyses to determine where women fail to progress into STEM careers. While the dominant narrative is attributed to bias at the stage of career entry, our analysis shows that the gender gap in STEM careers emerges as early as middle school. This gap -- primarily in interests -- leads to different choices of fields to study. Thus, within STEM, women make up the majority of new PhDs in less math-intensive fields such as biology and psychology while men are the majority in the math-intensive fields.

Post-PhD, on average men and women do have somewhat different career progression primarily due to their different fields, and also to their different choices about types of jobs. For instance, in our work on scientists' salaries, we find that STEM PhD female graduates earn approximately 18% less than men on average but that this is primarily due to the fields that they have entered and the jobs that they have chosen to take. Particularly, women tend to choose academic jobs while more men go to industry jobs. The gender gap in salaries that is unexplained by field, job sector, worktime, career length, and educational background is about 4.5% (as shown in the accompanying figure). It is also differs by family status.

To those who think STEM academia is biased against women, in our work on the probability of being hired into a tenure track job post-PhD and in our reviews of other studies on this, we find no evidence of gender bias against women from equivalent fields and backgrounds. We do, however, find that women with young children will be likely to eschew tenure-track jobs; and we know from other studies that women are less likely to apply for tenure track jobs. Similarly, our work and others' has shown that women are less like to apply (and to re-apply) for government research grants. There are broad implications of these conclusion for both the development of scientific human capital and for human resource policies within STEM occupations.  If having women enter math-intensive STEM fields is our goal, interventions are needed in middle school and high school to educate and stimulate interest of women in these fields. If our goal is to have more women engaged in STEM research across all fields, we need more research to know if structural barriers are keeping many women with children from entering intensive research jobs. This research might point the direction effective policies should take. 

In other research supported by this grant, Dr. Kahn has used the NSF's Survey of Doctorate Recipients to investigate how the careers of foreigners who receive US STEM PhDs subsequently have developed. We have found that delays in obtaining employment-based permanent residency status due to suddenly binding per-country limits on Chinese and Indians with advanced educations have negatively impacted the likelihood that Chinese and Indian PhD graduates remain in the US after their studies. Chinese and Indians are likely to be in fields of study that have been crucial in stimulating US economic growth yet enroll relatively few natives.
